title-group.article-title: IRTPRO 2.1 for Windows (Item Response Theory for Patient-Reported Outcomes)

article-meta.aff: 2Graduate Management Admission Council, Reston, VA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Insu Paek, Educational Psychology & Learning Systems, Florida State University, 3204D Stone Building, 1114 W. Call St., Tallahassee, FL 32306-4453, USA. Email: ipaek@fsu.edu

abstract.p: This article reviews a new item response theory (IRT) model estimation program, IRTPRO 2.1, for Windows that is capable of unidimensional and multidimensional IRT model estimation for existing and user-specified constrained IRT models for dichotomously and polytomously scored item response data.

sec.title: Program Description
sec.p: Item response theory (IRT) has been widely used in educational and psychological testing applications such as scaling, equating, computerized adaptive testing, and standard setting, to name a few. For successful applications of IRT, developing software programs that provide stable estimation of model parameters, a user-friendly interface, and thorough output is quintessential. In the past, for the unidimensional modeling, IRT software such as BILOG-MG (Zimowski, Muraki, Mislevy, & Bock, 2003), PARSCALE (Muraki & Bock, 2003), MULTILOG (Thissen, 2003), and WINSTEPS (Linacre, 2011) have played key roles in numerous applications of IRT. For multidimensional modeling, IRT software such as TESTFACT (Bock et al., 2003), NOHARM (Fraser & McDonald, 1988), Mplus (Muthén & Muthén, 2006), ConQuest (Wu, Adams, & Wilson, 1998), and BMIRT (Yao, 2003) have been used for psychometric analyses and research.

A new IRT program, IRTPRO (Cai, Thissen, & du Toit, 2011), was released in October 2011. IRTPRO is comprehensive in its modeling capacity and estimation approaches. In addition to computing item statistics and descriptive test statistics based on the classical test theory, it is capable of fitting a variety of IRT models to dichotomously and/or polytomously scored item response data, which include one-parameter logistic model (1PLM), two-parameter logistic model (2PLM), and three-parameter logistic model (3PLM), rating scale model (RSM), partial credit model (PCM), generalized partial credit model (GPCM), graded response model (GRM), nominal model (NM), multidimensional versions of all the preceding models, testlet response theory, bifactor versions of all of the preceding models, and multidimensional (as well as unidimensional) models with user-specified constraints in multiple groups. The focus of this article is on the introduction of the IRTPRO program, therefore, detailed comparisons with all those existing programs or assessment of IRTPRO’s model parameter recovery is beyond the scope of the current review. However, a few major differences from the authors’ point of view may be addressed compared with those aforementioned IRT programs. First of all, all the aforementioned existing programs except Mplus provide a single estimation algorithm option. IRTPRO provides three primary approaches to estimate structural parameters of a specified model: Bock–Aitkin approach with expectation–maximization algorithm (BAEM; Bock & Aitkin, 1981), adaptive quadrature (ADQ; Schilling & Bock, 2005), and Metropolis–Hastings Robbins–Monro (MH-RM; Cai, 2010a, 2010b). The previous existing IRT programs use either the BAEM type approach or joint maximum-likelihood estimation (MLE) method or a full Bayesian approach. Mplus provides limited-information and full-information ML approaches in addition to the Bayesian approach with Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC; but it is limited up to the two-parameter IRT model parameterization for dichotomously scored data). Second, IRTPRO provides an efficient alternative to MCMC or Gaussian ADQ for very high-dimensional model estimation. It is well known that estimation of an IRT model with a large number of dimensions is practically very challenging and time-consuming. The MH-RM algorithm in IRTPRO is specifically suited for such a high-dimensional problem. Third, IRTPRO provides an efficient error covariance matrix estimation algorithm of the supplemented EM (S-EM). Rather than approximating the observed information matrix as a diagonal matrix, it estimates all elements in the observed matrix accurately, which can be useful for, for example, the Wald type testing. Readers interested in more details of these features and understanding the degree of IRTPRO’s performance in terms of model parameter recovery are referred to Cai (2008, 2010a, 2010b, 2010c) and Cai, Yang, and Hansen (2011).

IRTPRO has multidimensional capability for existing popular unidimensional IRT and user-specified constrained models. In addition, compared with the popular existing IRT software mentioned above, some distinct features of IRTPRO can be summarized as follows. Among other things, IRTPRO offers

list-item.p: implementation of relatively new estimation methods: efficient two-tier generalized dimension reduction approach (Cai, 2010c), ADQ approach, and MH-RM algorithms;

provision of more accurate standard error calculation of structural parameters than aforementioned existing IRT software (Cai, 2008), which facilitates an updated version of Lord’s Wald test for differential item functioning (DIF) analysis for both unidimensional and multidimensional models in more than two groups;
new parameterization for the NM with Fourier and identity bases as provisions for a multidimensional NM (Thissen, Cai, & Bock, 2010);
provision of S−X2 for item fit statistic (Orlando & Thissen, 2000) and M2 for overall model-data fit (Maydeu-Olivares & Joe, 2005, 2006);
provision of a local dependence measure (using a statistic by Chen & Thissen, 1997);

an updated Lord–Wingersky algorithm for hierarchical item factor models that produces summed score to expected a posteriori (EAP) scale score translations for two-tier, bifactor, testlet, and unidimensional models (Cai, 2011); and

enhanced user interface to implement a specified model estimation. (For typical model calibrations, user requirements to know the necessary program commands are minimal, and specification of the model constraints for a user-specified modeling is very efficient and intuitive by using the window interface.)

sec.p: IRTPRO does not have any imposed limit on the total number of items and examinees for analyses. The actual maximum test length and maximum sample sizes that can be analyzed are decided by the size of available memory in a user’s computer and the choice of model estimation algorithm. For person ability θ estimation, IRTPRO provides EAP, maximum a posteriori (MAP; or Bayes modal estimator), and EAP for summed scores (Thissen, Nelson, Rosa, & McLeod, 2001). The current version of IRTPRO does not support the ML estimator for θ, although one can approximate the ML estimates via the choice of a diffuse prior ability distribution in the estimation of θ.

sec.title: Program Interface
sec.p: IRTPRO offers easy-to-use graphical user interface (GUI).1 Installing the program is done by just one click of the setup execution file after one downloads the setup program. The whole installation process takes less than a few minutes. When the program is installed, “IRTPRO21” and “IRTPRO Examples” folders are created under the program files directory and under the root (e.g., C:\) directory, respectively. The program installation takes about 38.3 MB in the hard drive.

In IRTPRO, an item response input data file needs to be converted to *.ssig file, which is the IRTPRO program data file. IRTPRO can import various types of data files (e.g., excel file, SPSS file, SAS file, Splus file, and ASCII tab-delimited, fixed format, or comma delimited file) and convert them into *.ssig files. Once the *.ssig file is created, running standard IRT models is straightforward. For example, after opening an *.ssig file for dichotomous responses, 6 to 10 mouse clicks are often sufficient for a user to run the 2PL model (using default options) and obtain item parameter estimate output (and person ability estimate output if requested) without manually writing any syntax inside the IRTPRO program. Figure 1 shows two screenshots from IRTPRO in estimating the 3PL model. The first screenshot (Figure 1a) illustrates how to specify the 3PLM instead of the 2PLM, which is the default dichotomous response model. In the model window, one can choose “3PL” for the 3PL model estimation. The second screenshot (Figure 1b) illustrates specifying a beta distribution prior for the guessing parameter in the 3PLM. The two parameter values for the beta distribution were specified as 5 and 17 in the “Prior Value” window. Some IRT experts might even feel concerns over this very simple implementation in IRTPRO for potential abuse of the IRT models without understanding them, but it seems that for routinized operational type of work, and for beginners who are learning IRT and its applications, this efficient execution of typical IRT models is of virtue. All command syntax is automatically written and updated and saved in a command file (*.irtpro), reflecting user’s choice of options in GUI. The program will automatically repopulate the dialog boxes based on the syntax specified in a command file. Users have the option to create the syntax directly in a plain text editor or modify from an automatically generated *.irtpro file. From experienced IRT program users’ point of view, the difficulty level of understanding the IRTPRO syntax and writing it in the *.irtpro file would be considered similar to or slightly less than the existing aforementioned IRT software syntax. This is partly because IRTPRO simplifies input data reading by menu option clicking through the window interface and users do not need to provide Fortran type input command lines for data reading (e.g., 4A1, 2X, 6A1), as in some of the aforementioned existing IRT software.

caption.p: Screenshots of the window user interface in IRTPRO specifying (a) the 3PLM and (b) a prior distribution for the guessing parameters in the 3PLM.

sec.p:
To grasp the efficiency of the program estimation in IRTPRO, three dichotomously scored data sets and one polytomously scored data set were used to estimate 2PLM, 3PLM, GRM, and multidimensional 2PLM. The computer used for the IRTPRO run was a laptop equipped with Intel Core i7 CPU 2.00 GHz, 8 GB memory in Windows 7, 64-bit operating system. Note that these analyses here are to provide a sense of the efficiency of IRTPRO. Again, readers who are interested in more details of the IRTPRO’s performance should be referred to Cai (2008, 2010a, 2010b, 2010c) and Cai et al. (2011). The first data set consisted of 40 items and 1,000 examinees. With all default options (meaning that BAEM was used), and S-EM computation of accurate item parameter covariance matrix, plus requesting EAP scores for examinees, the 2PLM parameters and EAPs for 1,000 examinees were estimated with successful convergence using a total processing time of 3.39 s. The default estimation in IRTPRO is pure marginal MLE, where only θ is assumed to follow a distribution (normal distribution in IRTPRO). It is well known that the 3PLM is hardest to estimate due to the presence of the low asymptotes in the model. For the 3PLM estimation with the second data that consisted of 40 items and 2,000 examinees, the authors specified prior distributions for the slope parameters and the pseudo-guessing parameters,
a
i
( slope
parameter ) ~ log - normal ( 0 , .
5
2
)
, and
g
i
( pseudo - guessing
parameter ) ~ beta ( 5 , 17 )
. The window user interface (the “Priors” option menus under the “Options” menu), as shown in Figure 1, makes it simple to specify prior(s) for the slope, difficulty, or pseudo-guessing parameters. One can specify priors for the entire items or part of the items. IRTPRO allows univariate prior distributions (beta, logit-normal, normal, and log-normal) on structural parameters (e.g., beta prior for the lower asymptote in the 3PLM as in this example run). IRTPRO estimated the 3PLM parameters and EAPs for 2,000 examinees without any convergence issues, with a total processing time of 5.41 s. The third data set had 20 items with Likert-type style—five-options per item (scored 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4) and 500 examinees. IRTPRO finished the GRM parameter and 500 EAPs estimation without any convergence issues using a total of 3.60 s. Given that the default convergence criteria used in IRTPRO in the estimation cycles are stricter than the aforementioned existing IRT software, IRTPRO appears to be fast and efficient for these unidimensional model runs. The last data set analyzed was dichotomously scored data and consisted of 30 items and 1,000 examinees. The four-dimensional 2PLM was run with the MH-RM estimation algorithm and took a total of 34.44 s to finish.

All model runs in IRTPRO can be implemented with ease using the user-friendly graphical interface that does not require memorizing critical command syntax. IRTPRO also provides plots of item characteristic curves, item and test information functions, standard error of measurement curves, and test characteristic curves for which users are allowed to select desired colors, styles of the graphs, and so on, and can be copied and pasted into word processing documents as publication-quality graphics.

sec.title: Documentation
sec.p: The IRPRO user guide comes with the purchase of the program. It is accessible under the “Help” menu. The user guide is comprehensive in terms of the program interface and expository examples.2 It is 227 pages. This is partly due to IRTPRO’s flexibility to cover a wide variety of IRT models and partly due to the detailed explanation for examples and user interface using the screenshots of the IRTPRO implementation. Chapters 1 and 2 explain mostly about user interface. Chapters 3 and 4 explain importing data into IRTPRO and classical test theory summary statistics. Chapters 5 through 7 cover unidimensional IRT models, including the multiple group IRT model and DIF, and multidimensional IRT models. The focus on these chapters is not on theoretical explanation of the models but on applications of the models using IRTPRO. The IRTPRO screenshots included in these chapters are helpful, especially for beginners who are learning about how to use IRTPRO and IRT in general. Chapter 8 explains the person ability estimators available in IRTPRO and how to use them in the IRTPRO. Chapters 9 and 10 explain how to obtain graphs (e.g., test information function, item characteristic curves) provided by IRTPRO. Chapter 11 provides how to implement each of the three primary estimation methods which IRTPRO uses with a brief explanation of each estimation method. BAEM is well known in the IRT community. Both ADQ and MH-RM are much less known to IRT practitioners and users than BAEM, especially MH-RM as a recently proposed estimation approach for high-dimensional model estimations. In high-dimensional IRT modeling, using a fixed set of (quadrature) nodes approach as in BAEM can easily become quite inefficient and challenging because of the rapidly increasing number of nodes as the number of dimensions increases (e.g., 11 nodes for a dimension: for two-dimensional case, 11 × 11 = 121; for three-dimensional case, 11 × 11 × 11 = 1,331; the default number of nodes in BAEM for a unidimensional analysis is 49, which is quite high). For a given number of dimensions, ADQ may be useful because it chooses the point of nodes effectively, which lead to using fewer nodes than a fixed node approach to have an equivalent or higher level of efficiency in estimating the model. For two- or three-dimensional modeling, ADQ may be an alternative to a fixed node approach in BAEM, but ultimately, ADQ would have the same issue as a fixed node approach such as BAEM as the number of dimensions increases beyond 4 or more. MH-RM was proposed to cope with multidimensional analysis when the number of dimensions is greater than 3 or 4, and implemented in IRTPRO. Given ADQ and especially MH-RM’s relative “newness,” some IRT practitioners and applied researchers may want to understand more about technical aspects of these estimation methods, but unfortunately the current user’s guide focuses on how to use in IRTPRO, and does not provide appropriate amount of technical details of these methods for intermediate or highly experienced IRT practitioners or researchers who are exposed to these estimation methods for the first time. Those who desire to know more about these new estimation methods are referred to the research articles cited in the user’s guide. Chapter 12 provides an explanation of IRTPRO command syntax. One should have little or no problem creating his or her own command file (*.irtpro) based on this chapter’s information and the automatically generated syntax files using the window interface. The final chapter contains all references.

IRTPRO offers a separate help menu in the program, where one can obtain information about the model specification, options, and command syntax by searching a keyword, by index, or by content (“Help Topics Under Help” in the menu) in detail. Online help is also offered when purchasing the program. One can send an e-mail of queries about the program and its use to Scientific Software International.

sec.title: Output
sec.p: The IRTPRO output is extensive. When default options are used, IRTPRO provides *-ssc.htm, *-irt.htm, *.irtpro, and *.irtplot files. The *-irt.htm file has detailed estimation results. It starts with the user comments, if there are any. Following this, the *-irt.htm file shows the model parameter estimates, S−X2 item fit statistics, population parameter estimates with their standard errors, local dependence statistics, item information function values for each of the items at θ ranging from −2.8 to 2.8 by increment of 0.4, marginal reliability estimate based on total test information function, −2 log likelihood, Akaike information criterion (AIC), Bayesian information criterion (BIC), overall model-data fit statistics based on all possible item response pattern frequencies (which is calculated only when sufficient frequencies are found in the data), Maydeu-Olivares and Joe’s M2 statistic (another overall model-data fit statistic), data and model specification information (e.g., sample size, the model name), model estimation control values (e.g., convergence criteria), model processing time, output file names, and diagnostics for convergence and numerical stability. The *-ssc.htm file is a summary file for the IRT scoring run, which contains model parameter estimates (without their standard errors), specifications of the model used for each of the items, data summary, the type of theta estimator, and output files’ names with their directory. The *.irtpro file is a command syntax file. If one uses the window interface to execute his or her model estimation, IRTPRO creates this syntax file automatically and use it for initiating the estimation. The *.irtplot file is for producing graphs. It shows item characteristic curves, item information, combined plot where item information and item characteristic curves are shown together, test information with a conditional standard error curve, and test characteristic curve.

On users’ request, IRTPRO saves estimates and standard errors for items and θs in separate *-prm.txt and *-sco.txt files, respectively, each of which writes item (or person) estimates and its standard errors columnwise. These output files for person and item estimates having a fixed format are helpful for reading the estimates into another program and conducting secondary analyses (e.g., person ability estimation with fixed item parameters or IRT person estimates as an outcome variable in a regression analysis).

If classical item analysis is requested (“Traditional Summed Score Statistics” under the “Analysis” menu), a *-sss.htm file is created. Major output in the file includes item score average, item score standard deviation, item-total correlation, coefficient alpha when the item of interest is removed from the total test, and frequency analysis for each item category, including the missing category.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: IRTPRO has many new features compared with the aforementioned existing IRT software. First of all, it implements new estimation methods, new item, and overall model-data fit indices and has capacity to estimate a wide variety of existing and user-specified constrained IRT models. The efficiency and effectiveness of the IRTPRO’s new high-dimensional model estimation especially deserve attention. In addition, IRTPRO has an excellent GUI and practitioners or beginners with limited knowledge about IRT can easily operate the program following the window user interface for typical IRT model estimations for dichotomous or polytomous or mixture item response format data.

A few points worth noting for a future version of IRTPRO are as follows. First, given that MLE θ is used as one of the IRT person scoring (e.g., some statewide large-scale assessment programs), it would be desirable to have the availability of MLE for θ as an option in the program. Second, the current version of IRTPRO uses the logistic response function only, and it does not provide an option of the scaling factor D = 1.7 for the normal ogive model approximation. Adding the option of
D = 1 . 7
might be considered useful for some users.

Overall, the efficiency of model estimation and easy operations with many new features addressed earlier would make IRTPRO attractive to practitioners and researchers in educational and psychological measurement and testing and in patient-reported outcomes measurement.

list-item.p: Program Name: IRTPRO (Item Response Theory for Patient-Reported Outcomes)
Publisher: Scientific Software International, 7383 North Lincoln Avenue, Suite 100, Lincolnwood, IL 60615-4530, USA
Email: irt@ssicentral.com for IRT questions sales@ssicentral.com for all installation and activation problems
URL: http://www.ssicentral.com
Price: US$495.00 (for a new single-user license)
System Requirement: Pentium 233 MHz processor or faster with at least 65 MB of RAM Computer running Windows XP or Windows 7
Capabilities: Unidimensional and multidimensional IRT model estimation for dichotomously scored and polytomously scored item response data

app.title: Appendix
app.p:
Based on Thissen and Steinberg’s (1986) framework on popular item response theory (IRT) models, IRTPRO introduced a new parameterization for nominal model (NM). Because generalized partial credit model (GPCM) is a special case of NM, IRTPRO uses the general new parameterization for NM to estimate NM, GPCM, and consequently partial credit model (PCM) and rating scale model (RSM), which are submodels of GPCM. For a given item, the slope and intercept parameters of NM in IRTPRO are parameterized as
a *
= a T α
and
c *
= T γ
, where T is a contrast matrix that consists of a linear column and a Fourier basis. This T matrix is called “Trend” in IRTPRO and used as default. Thus, with this default Trend matrix, one can impose constraints on α and γ, so that the slope a* and the intercept c* can have the parameterizations required by GPCM, PCM, or RSM. Readers who are interested in the technical aspect of the new parameterization approach and how the constraints explained below leads to the RSM are referred to Thissen and Steinberg (1986) and Thissen et al. (2010). Here, the authors explain the constraints required to implement RSM in two approaches. The first approach is the common “a” (slope) approach, and the second is the Rasch-style approach, where all slopes are fixed as unity. For simplicity, suppose that we have a five-item test and each item has four ordered categories (e.g., 0, 1, 2, and 3). Then the number of gamma elements in γ for an item is 3 (γ1, γ2, and γ3). Assuming the default Trend for γ is used.

sec.title: RSM With the Common “a” Approach
sec.p:
In this approach, the population distribution for θ is
N ( 0 , 1 )
, which is default in IRTPRO.

list-item.p: Choose GPCM in the model option.
Go to the “constraint” option.
Use equality constraint for all “a” (slopes) across all items.
Use equality constraint for all γ2 across all items.
Use equality constraint for all γ3 across all items.

sec.title: RSM With the Rasch-Style Approach
sec.p:
In this approach, the appropriate parameterization for the population distribution θ is
N ( 0 ,
σ
2
)
. Note that when estimating the Rasch model for dichotomous responses, where all slopes are unity, or the Rasch-style PCM implementation, where all slopes are unity, the same population distribution parameterization should be made. IRTPRO has the capacity to impose constraint not only on the item parameters but also the population θ distribution parameters as well, so one can fix the mean as zero and set the variance as a free parameter. As a side note, when
N ( 0 ,
σ
2
)
is used in the Rasch-style model estimation and EAP person ability is requested, IRTPRO by default uses
N ( 0 ,
σ
^
2
)
for the EAP estimation, not
N ( 0 , 1 )
.

list-item.p: Choose GPCM in the model option.
Go to the “constraint” option.
Fix as unity all “a” (slopes) across all items.
Set the θ distribution variance as a free parameter while its mean is fixed to zero as default.
Use equality constraint for all γ2 across all items.
Use equality constraint for all γ3 across all items.

sec.p: Note that when estimating GPCM or PCM or RSM using the preceding constraints, IRTPRO provides the estimates for the original NM parameterization and the constrained model. The IRTPRO output for GPCM (consequently, PCM and RSM) shows item slope (ai), item location (bi), and step parameter (dik) estimates (i.e., the estimates of the following logit part of the item response function):

where ai and bi are the ith item slope and location, and dik is the ith item step parameter (
k = 0 ,
1 ,
2 , … , m − 1
). The preceding constraints make
a
i
= a
(the common “a” approach) or 1 (the Rasch-style approach) and
d
ik
=
d
k
for RSM.

ack.p: The authors thank Dr. Li Cai for his valuable comments on this review and the program use.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

The student version of the IRTPRO program is freely downloadable (http://www.ssicentral.com/irt/downloads.html). The free IRTPRO version also includes the full manual, the IRTPRO user guide, which contains many useful screenshots to show the user-friendly features of the program.

IRTPRO uses a new parameterization for the nominal response model that is used to estimate nominal model (NM), generalized partial credit model (GPCM), partial credit model (PCM), and rating scale model (RSM; three models as special cases of NM). IRTPRO has NM and GPCM as model choice options but does not have PCM and RSM as the model choice option. Thus, users should provide proper constraints to implement PCM and RSM. The constraint for PCM is straightforward as usual, which is an equality constraint on item slopes across all items under the GPCM (if one chooses an equal slope constraint approach for PCM). RSM requires more constraints than PCM. Because of the new parameterization that uses a linear column and a Fourier basis in the contrast matrix, the appropriate constraints for RSM may not be straightforward to practitioners. (Moreover, the current IRTPRO user guide does not provide information on how to implement RSM.) The Appendix provides the constraints necessary to implement RSM in IRTPRO.
